elements.content: Thirteen new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), namely, [Zn2(L1)2(biim-4)(H2O)] (1), [Cd(HL1)2(biim-4)] (2), [Cd(HL2)2(biim-4)] (3), [Cd(HL3)2(biim-4)] (4), [Zn2(L4)2(biim-4)(H2O)] (5), [Cd(HL4)2(biim-4)] (6), [Zn2(L5)2(biim-4)(H2O)] (7), [Cd(HL5)2(biim-4)1.5]·H2O (8), [Zn2(L6)2(biim-4)(H2O)] (9), [Cd(HL6)2(biim-4)] (10), [Zn2(L7)2(biim-4)2]·H2O (11), [Cd2(L7)2(biim-4)2(H2O)]·H2O (12), and [Zn(HL8)(biim-4)]·0.5H2O (13), where H2L1 = salicylic acid, H2L2 = 3-methylsalicylic acid, H2L3 = 4-methylsalicylic acid, H2L4 = 4-chlorosalicylic acid, H2L5 = 5-chlorosalicylic acid, H2L6 = 5-bromosalicylic acid, H2L7 = 5-nitrosalicylic acid, H3L8 = 5-sulfosalicylic acid, and biim-4 = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole), have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1 and 5 are isomorphous, and show the same 3-connected 103-ths net. Compound 2 possesses a meso-helical chain structure. Compound 3 shows a zero-dimensional (0D) dimeric molecular structure, which is linked by π–π interactions into a two-dimensional (2D) supramolecular assembly. Compounds 4 and 6 exhibit similar one-dimensional (1D) chains, which are extended into different 2D supramolecular layers via C–H···O and C–H···Cl hydrogen-bonding interactions, respectively. Compound 9 is isomorphous with 7 and displays a typical 3D diamond framework. Compound 8 shows an unusual 2D → 3D polythreading array. Compound 10 furnishes a 2D supramolecular (44)-sql network formed by C–H···Br hydrogen-bonding interactions. Compounds 11 and 12 exhibit binodal (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with (4.53.72)(4.52.83) and (42.62.82)(42.6.82.10) topologies, respectively. Compound 13 has a 3D 4-fold interpenetrating diamond framework. The TGA and luminescent properties of 1–13 have also been investigated in detail.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have received remarkable attention owing to their potential applications as functional materials as well as their fascinating structural topologies. Usually, the structure of the resultant framework is mainly influenced by various factors such as the pH values, reaction temperatures, neutral ligands, organic anions, central metals, and so on. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received remarkable attention owing to their potential applications as functional materials as well as their fascinating structural topologies. Usually, the structure of the resultant framework is mainly influenced by various factors such as the pH values, reaction temperatures, neutral ligands, organic anions, central metals, and so on. In this regard, the organic anions play an important role in the construction of MOFs with novel structures. So far, a large number of metal carboxylates have been extensively synthesized and characterized. Carboxylic acids are selected as good organic ligands because they can coordinate with metal ions in various modes, such as monodentate, bidentate, and tridentate.

elements.content: Recently, salicylic derivatives have attracted considerable attention not only for their structural varieties but also for their biological applications and spectroscopic and electrochemical behaviors. From the coordination chemistry point of view, the presence of the hydroxyl group in salicylic derivatives allows the formation of six-membered rings which can stabilize the solid frameworks. In addition, the hydroxyl groups in salicylate ligands are involved in the formation of intra- and/or intermolecular hydrogen bonds and assist the formation of multidimensional assemblies. So far, MOFs with diverse structure types, constructed by salicylate ligands and rigid N-donor ligands, have been studied. However, the ones based on salicylate ligands and flexible N-donor bridging ligands, especially bis(imidazole) ligands, are rarely reported. Among the N-donor bridging ligands, 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole) (biim-4) as an important member of the flexible N-donor ligands has received intense interest.

elements.content:
The ligand biim-4 was synthesized according to the reported procedures. All other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received.

Physical Measurements

The C, H, and N elemental analysis were conducted on a Perkin–Elmer 2400CHN elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of the samples was collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 5 to 50°. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 40 to 800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a FLSP920 Edinburgh fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The ligand biim-4 was synthesized according to the reported procedures. All other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received.

Physical Measurements

The C, H, and N elemental analysis were conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 2400CHN elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data of the samples was collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 5 to 50°. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from 40 to 800 °C under nitrogen atmosphere. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a FLSP920 Edinburgh fluorescence spectrometer at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of H2L1 (13.8 mg, 0.1 mmol), biim-4 (19.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (22.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), NaOH (4.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and water (8 mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave reactor (15 mL) and heated at 140 °C for 3 days. After the mixture had been cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C·h–1, colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained in a 58% yield based on Zn(II). Anal. elements.content: Crystallographic diffraction data for compounds 1–13 were recorded on a Oxford Diffraction Gemini R CCD with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. All non-hydrogen atoms were easily found from the Fourier difference maps and refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The disordered atoms (C10 and C10′ for 1, C4, C4′, C5, C5′, O6, and O6′ for 2, C4, C4′, C5, C5′, N2, and N2′ for 4, C4 and C4′ for 7, C4 and C4′ for 9, and O4, O4′, O5, O5′, O6, and O6′ for 13) were split over two sites, with a total occupancy of 1. The hydrogen atoms of the disordered C and O atoms could not be positioned geometrically. Other hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the free water molecules in 8 and 11–13 were not included in the model. The topologies of compounds 1, 7, and 11–13 were analyzed by using OLEX program.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Crystallographic diffraction data for compounds 1-13 were recorded on a Oxford Diffraction Gemini R CCD with graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. All non-hydrogen atoms were easily found from the Fourier difference maps and refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The disordered atoms (C10 and C10' for 1, C4, C4', C5, C5', O6, and O6' for 2, C4, C4', C5, C5', N2, and N2' for 4, C4 and C4' for 7, C4 and C4' for 9, and O4, O4', O5, O5', O6, and O6' for 13) were split over two sites, with a total occupancy of 1. The hydrogen atoms of the disordered C and O atoms could not be positioned geometrically. Other hydrogen atoms of water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps and refined with isotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the free water molecules in 8 and 11-13 were not included in the model. The topologies of compounds 1, 7, and 11-13 were analyzed by using OLEX program.

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two Zn(II) cations, two L1 anions, two half biim-4 ligands, and one coordinated water molecule. As shown in Figure a, Zn1 is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two L1 anions (Zn1–O1 = 2.0512(2), Zn1–O2 = 2.447(2), Zn1–O4 = 1.942(2) Å), one coordinated water molecule (Zn1–O1W = 2.018(3) Å), and one nitrogen atom from one biim-4 ligand (Zn1–N1 = 1.977(2) Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramid coordination environment. Zn2 atom also shows a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry, coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate and two phenolic hydroxyl groups of two L1 anions (Zn2–O1 = 2.121(2), Zn2–O3 = 1.951(2), Zn2–O5#1 = 2.098(2), Zn2–O6#1 = 1.959(2) Å), and one nitrogen atom from one biim-4 ligand (Zn2–N3 = 2.009(3) Å). As shown in Figure b, adjacent Zn(II) atoms are bridged by two kinds of L1 anions in modes I and II (Scheme S1 in the ), yielding a wavelike chain. The chains are linked by one kind of biim-4 ligand to generate a 2D layer (Figure c). Furthermore, the layers are bridged by another kind of biim-4 ligand to form a complicated 3D framework (). The two kinds of biim-4 ligands display “S” conformations with Zn···Zn separations of 12.5217(2) and 12.5298(5) Å, respectively (Scheme S2a in the ). In addition, there are hydrogen-bonding interactions between O1W and phenoxy oxygen atoms (O1W–H1A···O6#1 and O1W–H1B···O3#4), which further stabilize the 3D framework of 1 ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure of [Zn2(L1)2(biim-4)(H2O)] (1)

Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that the asymmetric unit of 1 contains two Zn(II) cations, two L1 anions, two half biim-4 ligands, and one coordinated water molecule. As shown in Figure a, Zn1 is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two L1 anions (Zn1-O1 = 2.0512(2), Zn1-O2 = 2.447(2), Zn1-O4 = 1.942(2) Å), one coordinated water molecule (Zn1-O1W = 2.018(3) Å), and one nitrogen atom from one biim-4 ligand (Zn1-N1 = 1.977(2) Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramid coordination environment. Zn2 atom also shows a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry, coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate and two phenolic hydroxyl groups of two L1 anions (Zn2-O1 = 2.121(2), Zn2-O3 = 1.951(2), Zn2-O5#1 = 2.098(2), Zn2-O6#1 = 1.959(2) Å), and one nitrogen atom from one biim-4 ligand (Zn2-N3 = 2.009(3) Å). As shown in Figure b, adjacent Zn(II) atoms are bridged by two kinds of L1 anions in modes I and II (Scheme S1 in the ), yielding a wavelike chain. The chains are linked by one kind of biim-4 ligand to generate a 2D layer (Figure c). Furthermore, the layers are bridged by another kind of biim-4 ligand to form a complicated 3D framework (). The two kinds of biim-4 ligands display "S" conformations with Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separations of 12.5217(2) and 12.5298(5) Å, respectively (Scheme S2a in the ). In addition, there are hydrogen-bonding interactions between O1W and phenoxy oxygen atoms (O1W-H1A⋅⋅⋅O6#1 and O1W-H1B⋅⋅⋅O3#4), which further stabilize the 3D framework of 1 ().

elements.content: Topologically, both Zn1 and Zn2 atoms can be reduced to 3-connected nodes, and L1 anions and biim-4 ligands can be considered as linkers. Therefore, the framework of 1 can be described as a 3-connected 103-ths net (Figure d).
elements.clean_text: Topologically, both Zn1 and Zn2 atoms can be reduced to 3-connected nodes, and L1 anions and biim-4 ligands can be considered as linkers. Therefore, the framework of 1 can be described as a 3-connected 103-ths net (Figure d).

elements.content: The structure of compound [Zn2(L4)2(biim-4)(H2O)] (5) is essentially isomorphous with 1. There are small differences between them. First, the coordination number of metal atom is different. In compound 5, Zn1 is four-coordinated in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, while, in compound 1, Zn1 is five-coordinated in a trigonal bipyramid coordination environment. Second, the coordination modes of the organic anions are different. In compound 5, L4 anions adopt the mode II, whereas L1 anions employ the modes I and II in compound 1. Besides, C atoms from the imidazole ring and methylene of the same biim-4 ligand donate H atoms to 4-position chlorine atoms of L4 anions, yielding intermolecular C1–H1···Cl2#5 and C4–H4B···Cl1#6 hydrogen bonding interactions (). The asymmetric unit of compound 5 is shown in the (Figure S3).

Second, the coordination modes of the organic anions are different. In compound 5, L4 anions adopt the mode II, whereas L1 anions employ the modes I and II in compound 1. Besides, C atoms from the imidazole ring and methylene of the same biim-4 ligand donate H atoms to 4-position chlorine atoms of L4 anions, yielding intermolecular C1-H1⋅⋅⋅Cl2#5 and C4-H4B⋅⋅⋅Cl1#6 hydrogen bonding interactions (). The asymmetric unit of compound 5 is shown in the  (Figure S3).

elements.content: When Zn(II) cations were replaced by Cd(II) cations, a quite different structure of 2 was obtained. As illustrated in Figure a, the structure of 2 contains one Cd(II) cation, two HL1 anions, and two half biim-4 ligands. Cd1 is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two HL1 anions (Cd1–O1 = 2.213(2), Cd1–O4 = 2.390(3), Cd1–O5 = 2.353(2) Å), and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Cd1–N1 = 2.221(3), Cd1–N3 = 2.207(3) Å), exhibiting a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry. Different from 1, the phenolic hydroxyl H atom of H2L1 is not deprotonated in 2. Two HL1 anions coordinate to Cd(II) atoms in modes III and IV (Scheme S1 in the ), yielding a [Cd(HL1)2] unit. The [Cd(HL1)2] units are further connected by two kinds of biim-4 ligands in zigzag and “Ω” conformations (Scheme S2b,c in the ) to generate a meso-helical chain (Figure b). Moreover, an intramolecular O3–H3′···O2 hydrogen-bonding interaction exists between O3 from the phenolic hydroxyl group and carboxylate oxygen O2 atom, which stabilizes the 1D chain structure of 2 ().

Structure of [Cd(HL1)2(biim-4)] (2)

When Zn(II) cations were replaced by Cd(II) cations, a quite different structure of 2 was obtained. As illustrated in Figure a, the structure of 2 contains one Cd(II) cation, two HL1 anions, and two half biim-4 ligands. Cd1 is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two HL1 anions (Cd1-O1 = 2.213(2), Cd1-O4 = 2.390(3), Cd1-O5 = 2.353(2) Å), and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Cd1-N1 = 2.221(3), Cd1-N3 = 2.207(3) Å), exhibiting a distorted trigonal bipyramid geometry. Different from 1, the phenolic hydroxyl H atom of H2L1 is not deprotonated in 2. Two HL1 anions coordinate to Cd(II) atoms in modes III and IV (Scheme S1 in the ), yielding a [Cd(HL1)2] unit. The [Cd(HL1)2] units are further connected by two kinds of biim-4 ligands in zigzag and "Ω" conformations (Scheme S2b,c in the ) to generate a meso-helical chain (Figure b). Moreover, an intramolecular O3-H3'⋅⋅⋅O2 hydrogen-bonding interaction exists between O3 from the phenolic hydroxyl group and carboxylate oxygen O2 atom, which stabilizes the 1D chain structure of 2 ().

elements.content: As illustrated in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 3 has one Cd(II) cation, two HL2 anions, and one biim-4 ligand. Cd(II) cation is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two HL2 anions (Cd1–O1 = 2.208(3), Cd1–O4 = 2.310(3), Cd1–O5 = 2.463(3) Å), and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Cd1–N1 = 2.228(3), Cd1–N4#1 = 2.217(3) Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramid sphere. Cd(II) atoms are coordinated by two HL2 anions to form a [Cd(HL2)2] unit. Two neighboring [Cd(HL2)2] units are linked by biim-4 ligands in “Ω” shaped conformations to generate a 0D dimeric structure.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [Cd(HL2)2(biim-4)] (3)

As illustrated in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 3 has one Cd(II) cation, two HL2 anions, and one biim-4 ligand. Cd(II) cation is five-coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two HL2 anions (Cd1-O1 = 2.208(3), Cd1-O4 = 2.310(3), Cd1-O5 = 2.463(3) Å), and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Cd1-N1 = 2.228(3), Cd1-N4#1 = 2.217(3) Å) in a distorted trigonal bipyramid sphere. Cd(II) atoms are coordinated by two HL2 anions to form a [Cd(HL2)2] unit. Two neighboring [Cd(HL2)2] units are linked by biim-4 ligands in "Ω" shaped conformations to generate a 0D dimeric structure.

elements.content: Notably, two types of π–π stackings exist in 3 (Figure b). The neighboring adjacent dimers interact through one type of π–π stacking between imidazole and adjacent benzene rings of HL2 anions with interplanar separation being 3.65 Å (the centroid–centroid and slippage distances of 3.75 and 0.85 Å), yielding a 1D tube-like chain along the a axis. Two adjacent chains are linked by another type of π–π stacking between two adjacent imidazole rings with interplanar separation being 3.62 Å (the centroid–centroid and slippage distances of 3.74 and 0.95 Å), generating a thick 2D supramolecular layer assembly (Figure c). Moreover, intramolecular O3–H3A···O2 and O6–H6···O5 hydrogen-bonding interactions exist among phenolic hydroxyl group and carboxylate oxygen atoms, which further stabilize the 2D supramolecular layer of 3 ().

Two adjacent chains are linked by another type of π-π stacking between two adjacent imidazole rings with interplanar separation being 3.62 Å (the centroid-centroid and slippage distances of 3.74 and 0.95 Å), generating a thick 2D supramolecular layer assembly (Figure c). Moreover, intramolecular O3-H3A⋅⋅⋅O2 and O6-H6⋅⋅⋅O5 hydrogen-bonding interactions exist among phenolic hydroxyl group and carboxylate oxygen atoms, which further stabilize the 2D supramolecular layer of 3 ().

elements.content: Compound 4 contains one Cd(II) cation, two HL3 anions, and one biim-4 ligand. Cd(II) cation adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry through coordinating to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two individual HL3 anions (Cd1–O1 = 2.446(2), Cd1–O2 = 2.328(2), Cd1–O1#1 = 2.446(2), Cd1–O2#1 = 2.329(2) Å), and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Cd1–N1 = 2.232(2) Å) (Figure a). Cd(II) atoms are connected by HL3 anions in mode III to form a [Cd(HL3)2] unit. Neighboring [Cd(HL3)2] units are further bridged by biim-4 ligands in zigzag conformations to yield a meso-helical chain along the c axis (). Furthermore, intramolecular O3–H3A···O1 hydrogen bonds exist between phenolic hydroxyl group and carboxylate oxygen O1 atom. Besides, the methyl group at the 4-position of HL3 anion donates a H atom to O3 of phenolic hydroxyl group, generating intermolecular C13–H13B···O3#3 interaction (), which extended the 1D chains into a 2D wavelike supramolecular layer parallel to the bc plane (Figure b).

Structure of [Cd(HL3)2(biim-4)] (4)

Compound 4 contains one Cd(II) cation, two HL3 anions, and one biim-4 ligand. Cd(II) cation adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry through coordinating to four carboxylate oxygen atoms from two individual HL3 anions (Cd1-O1 = 2.446(2), Cd1-O2 = 2.328(2), Cd1-O1#1 = 2.446(2), Cd1-O2#1 = 2.329(2) Å), and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Cd1-N1 = 2.232(2) Å) (Figure a). Cd(II) atoms are connected by HL3 anions in mode III to form a [Cd(HL3)2] unit. Neighboring [Cd(HL3)2] units are further bridged by biim-4 ligands in zigzag conformations to yield a meso-helical chain along the c axis (). Furthermore, intramolecular O3-H3A⋅⋅⋅O1 hydrogen bonds exist between phenolic hydroxyl group and carboxylate oxygen O1 atom. Besides, the methyl group at the 4-position of HL3 anion donates a H atom to O3 of phenolic hydroxyl group, generating intermolecular C13-H13B⋅⋅⋅O3#3 interaction (), which extended the 1D chains into a 2D wavelike supramolecular layer parallel to the bc plane (Figure b).

Different from 4, in 6, the C3 atom from the imidazole ring of biim-4 ligand donates a H atom to the 4-position chlorine (Cl1) atom of the HL4 anion, yielding a intermolecular C3–H3···Cl1#3 hydrogen-bonding interaction (), which link the 1D chains into a different 2D wavelike supramolecular layer parallel to the ac plane ().

elements.content: When the substituent group chlorine atom is at the 5-position of the benzene ring, a structurally different compound 7 was obtained. The asymmetric unit of 7 contains two unique Zn(II) atoms, two L5 anions, two half biim-4 ligands, and one coordinated water molecule (Figure a). Each Zn(II) atom is five-coordinated and exhibits a distorted trigonal bipyramid coordination environment. Zn1 is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two L5 anions (Zn1–O1 = 2.186(2), Zn1–O2 = 2.201(2), Zn1–O4 = 1.973(2) Å), one coordinated water molecule (Zn1–O1W = 2.028(2) Å), and one nitrogen atom from one biim-4 ligand (Zn1–N1 = 2.000(3) Å). However, Zn2 is surrounded by four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate and two phenolic hydroxyl groups of two L5 anions (Zn2–O1 = 2.051(2), Zn2–O5#1 = 2.061(2), Zn2–O3 = 1.985(2), Zn2–O6#1 = 1.995(2) Å), and one nitrogen atom from one biim-4 ligand (Zn2–N3 = 2.014(2) Å). Like that of 1, adjacent Zn(II) atoms are bridged by L5 anions in modes I and II to yield a wavelike 1D chain along the b axis. The 1D chains are then connected by one kind of biim-4 ligand to generate a 2D layer (Figure b). The layers are further linked by another kind of biim-4 ligand to form a 3D framework (). Two kinds of biim-4 ligands show distorted zigzag and zigzag conformations ().

elements.content: From the topological view, the dinuclear Zn(II) unit can be simplified as 4-connected node, and the biim-4 ligands can be considered as linkers. Thus, the structure of 7 is a typical diamond framework (Figure c). In addition, the 3D framework of 7 is stabilized by intermolecular O1W–H1A···O3#4 and O1W–H1B···O6#1 interactions among coordinated water molecule and phenoxy oxygen atoms (). Besides, the presence of 5-position chlorine atoms of the L5 anion allows the formation of C16–H16···Cl2#5 hydrogen-bonding interaction, which further stabilizes the 3D framework of 7.

elements.content: Compound 8 shows an unusual 2D → 3D polythreading array. As shown in Figure a, each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two HL5 anions (Cd1–O1 = 2.356(2), Cd1–O4 = 2.428(2), Cd1–O5 = 2.557(2) Å), and three nitrogen atoms from three biim-4 ligands (Cd1–N1 = 2.308(2), Cd1–N3 = 2.301(2), Cd1–N5 = 2.299(2) Å) in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Cd(II) atoms are bridged by three kinds of biim-4 ligands in zigzag and “S” conformations to yield a 3-connected hexagonal honeycomb 63-hcb net (Figure b). There are very large hexagonal windows with approximate dimensions of 24.873 × 16.52 Å built up by six Cd(II) atoms and six biim-4 ligands within the 2D motif. Notably, the HL5 anion containing O1 atom coordinate to Cd(II) in mode IV, which are just like open arms protruding from both sides of the 2D layers. Each dangling arm has an effectual length of about 7.6 Å. As a result, each hexagonal window is threaded by two arms above and below, thus resulting in a rare 2D → 3D polythreading motif (Figure c,d).

elements.content: Compound 10 exhibits a meso-helical 1D chain. As shown in Figure a, Cd1 atom shows a distorted trigonal bipyramid coordination geometry, coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two HL6 anions in modes III and IV (Cd1–O1 = 2.464(3), Cd1–O2 = 2.363(3), Cd1–O4 = 2.202(3) Å), and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Cd1–N1 = 2.201(3), Cd1–N3 = 2.233(3) Å). Cd(II) atoms are linked by two kinds of biim-4 ligands to generate a meso-helical chain (). Different from those of 2 and 4, the two kinds of biim-4 ligands in 10 display “S” and zigzag conformations with Cd···Cd distances of 12.6316(8) and 13.9624(8) Å, respectively. In addition, the phenolic hydroxyl groups donate H atoms to carboxylate oxygen atoms to yield intramolecular O3–H3A···O1 and O6–H6A···O5 hydrogen bonding interactions (). Besides, C9 from methylene of biim-4 ligand donates a H atom to the 5-position bromine atom to generate an intermolecular C9–H9B···Br2#3 hydrogen bonding interaction, which extends the 1D meso-helical chain into a 2D supramolecular (44)-sql network (Figure b).

elements.content: When H2L6 was replaced by H2L7, a structurally different compound 11 was obtained. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 11 contains two Zn(II) atoms, two L7 anions, three kinds of biim-4 ligands, and one free water molecule. Zn1 atom is four-coordinated by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two L7 anions (Zn1–O2 = 2.0024(1), Zn1–O7#1 = 2.0106(1) Å), and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Zn1–N1 = 1.9853(2), Zn1–N5 = 1.9955(2) Å) in a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment. Zn2 atom is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two L7 anions (Zn2–O1 = 2.0904(1), Zn2–O6 =2.0844(1), Zn2–O3 = 2.0579(2), Zn2–O8 = 2.0436(2) Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Zn2–N4#2 = 2.1369(2), Zn2–N7 = 2.2134(2) Å), showing a distorted ZnO4N2 octahedral coordination geometry. The L7 anions bridge the Zn1 and Zn2 atoms in mode II to yield a 1D chain (Figure b). The 1D chains are further linked by one kind of biim-4 ligand to generate a 2D layer (Figure c). In fact, there are three kinds of 2D layers constructed by the 1D chains and biim-4 ligands (). These three kinds of 2D layers link each other to generate a 3D extended framework.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 12 contains two crystallographically unique Cd(II) atoms, two L7 anions, three kinds of biim-4 ligands, one coordinated water molecule, and one free water molecule. The Cd1 atom is coordinated with two L7 anions via four carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd1–O1 = 2.467(2), Cd1–O2 = 2.394(2), Cd1–O6#2 = 2.478(2), Cd1–O7#2 = 2.480(2) Å), two biim-4 ligands via two nitrogen atoms (Cd1–N1 = 2.288(3), Cd1–N4#1 = 2.287(3) Å), and one coordinated water molecule (Cd1–O1W = 2.352(3) Å), displaying a distorted pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry (Figure a). Cd2 atom is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two L7 anions (Cd2–O1 = 2.288(2), Cd2–O3 = 2.254(2), Cd2–O6 = 2.267(2), Cd2–O8 = 2.213(2) Å) and two nitrogen atoms from two biim-4 ligands (Cd2–N5 = 2.360(3), Cd2–N7 = 2.275(3) Å) in a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. L7 anions bridge the Cd1 and Cd2 ions in mode I to yield a 1D chain (Figure b). The 1D chains are linked by one kind of biim-4 ligand to generate a 2D layer (Figure c). Similar to 11, there are also three kinds of 2D layers constructed by the 1D chains and biim-4 ligands in 12. These three kinds of layers constitute a 3D framework by sharing the Cd(II) atoms.

elements.content: The topological analysis of 13 reveals that it is a typically diamond framework containing large adamantanoid cages (Figure c). Because of the spacious nature of the single network, it allows three identical diamond frameworks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode, resulting in a 4-fold interpenetrating diamond array (Figure d).

Because of the spacious nature of the single network, it allows three identical diamond frameworks to interpenetrate it in a normal mode, resulting in a 4-fold interpenetrating diamond array (Figure d).

elements.content: The organic anions play a crucial role in determining the structures of MOFs. In this study, salicylic acid and seven different kinds of salicylic derivatives were used as the organic anions (Scheme ). The structural features of the salicylate ligands such as the types and sites of substituent groups are the underlying reason for the structural differences within this series of Zn/Cd compounds. We take Zn-containing compounds [Zn2(L1)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 1, [Zn2(L5)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 7, [Zn2(L7)2(biim-4)2]·H2O 11, and [Zn(HL8)(biim-4)]·0.5H2O 13 for example. Compared with the salicylic acid H2L1 for 1, the substituted salicylic acids, such as H2L5 (5-chlorosalicylic acid) for 7, H2L7 (5-nitrosalicylic acid) for 11, and H3L8 (5-sulfosalicylic acid) for 13, have additional substituent groups. Clearly, the differences of substituted groups in these acids result in the formation of 1, 7, 11, and 13 with quite distinct architectures. Compound 1 displays a 3D 103-ths net. Compound 7 shows a 3D diamond framework, whereas compound 13 has a 3D 4-fold interpenetrating diamond framework. Compound 11 is a binodal (4,4)-connected 3D framework with (4·53 ·72)(4·52 ·83) topology. It should be pointed out that although the architectures of 1 and [Zn2(L4)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 5 are very similar, some differences exist between them. Although 1 and 5 display the same 103-ths net, the coordination numbers of Zn(II) atoms, coordination modes of organic anions, and hydrogen-bonding interactions are slightly different between them. In 1, both Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are five-coordinated, while, in 5, Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are four- and five-coordinated, respectively. L1 anions in 1 adopt modes I and II to coordinate with Zn(II) atoms, but L4 anions in 5 only take mode II. Moreover, different from 1, the 4-position chlorine atom of L4 anion in 5 is involved in an additional intermolecular C–H···Cl hydrogen-bonding interaction. However, the coordination numbers of Zn(II) atoms, coordination modes of organic anions, hydrogen-bonding interactions, and the frameworks are very similar between compounds 7 and [Zn2(L6)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 9. The only difference between them is the substituent groups located in the 5-position of the substituted salicylic acids.

Effect of the Organic Anion on the Framework

The organic anions play a crucial role in determining the structures of MOFs. In this study, salicylic acid and seven different kinds of salicylic derivatives were used as the organic anions (Scheme ). The structural features of the salicylate ligands such as the types and sites of substituent groups are the underlying reason for the structural differences within this series of Zn/Cd compounds. We take Zn-containing compounds [Zn2(L1)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 1, [Zn2(L5)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 7, [Zn2(L7)2(biim-4)2]⋅H2O 11, and [Zn(HL8)(biim-4)]⋅0.5H2O 13 for example. Compared with the salicylic acid H2L1 for 1, the substituted salicylic acids, such as H2L5 (5-chlorosalicylic acid) for 7, H2L7 (5-nitrosalicylic acid) for 11, and H3L8 (5-sulfosalicylic acid) for 13, have additional substituent groups. Clearly, the differences of substituted groups in these acids result in the formation of 1, 7, 11, and 13 with quite distinct architectures. Compound 1 displays a 3D 103-ths net. Compound 7 shows a 3D diamond framework, whereas compound 13 has a 3D 4-fold interpenetrating diamond framework. Compound 11 is a binodal (4,4)-connected 3D framework with (4⋅53 ⋅72)(4⋅52 ⋅83) topology. It should be pointed out that although the architectures of 1 and [Zn2(L4)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 5 are very similar, some differences exist between them. Although 1 and 5 display the same 103-ths net, the coordination numbers of Zn(II) atoms, coordination modes of organic anions, and hydrogen-bonding interactions are slightly different between them. In 1, both Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are five-coordinated, while, in 5, Zn1 and Zn2 atoms are four- and five-coordinated, respectively. L1 anions in 1 adopt modes I and II to coordinate with Zn(II) atoms, but L4 anions in 5 only take mode II. Moreover, different from 1, the 4-position chlorine atom of L4 anion in 5 is involved in an additional intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen-bonding interaction. However, the coordination numbers of Zn(II) atoms, coordination modes of organic anions, hydrogen-bonding interactions, and the frameworks are very similar between compounds 7 and [Zn2(L6)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 9. The only difference between them is the substituent groups located in the 5-position of the substituted salicylic acids.

elements.content: Simultaneously, these structural differences caused by the substituent groups can also be supported by the Cd-containing compounds [Cd(HL1)2(biim-4)] 2, [Cd(HL2)2(biim-4)] 3, [Cd(HL3)2(biim-4)] 4, [Cd(HL4)2(biim-4)] 6, [Cd(HL5)2(biim-4)1.5]·H2O 8, [Cd(HL6)2(biim-4)] 10, and [Cd2(L7)2(biim-4)2(H2O)]·H2O 12. The substituted salicylic acids, such as H2L2 (3-methylsalicylic acid) for 3, H2L3 (4-methylsalicylic acid) for 4, H2L4 (4-chlorosalicylic acid) for 6, H2L5 (5-chlorosalicylic acid) for 8, H2L6 (5-bromosalicylic acid) for 10, and H2L7 (5-nitrosalicylic acid) for 12, contain additional substituent groups. These differences in the substituted groups have an important influence on the structures of the complexes. For example, compound 2 based on salicylic acid (H2L1) only displays a meso-helical chain structure, whereas compounds 3, 4, 6, and 10 exhibit different 2D supramolecular architectures. Compound 8 possesses a 2D → 3D polythreading array, whereas compound 12 displays a binodal (4,4)-connected 3D framework with (42.62.82)(42.6.82.10) topology. It should be pointed out that although 3, 4, 6, and 10 show similar 2D supramolecular architectures, some differences exist among them. For 3 and 4, although both HL2 and HL3 contain the methyl groups, their positions are completely different. The difference in the positions of the methyl groups is the underlying factor that leads to the complex structure differences. Compound 3 displays a 0D dimeric molecular structure, which is linked by π–π interactions into a 2D supramolecular architecture. However, compound 4 exhibits a 1D meso-helical chain, which is extended into a 2D wavelike layer parallel to the bc plane through C–H···O hydrogen bonds between the phenolic hydroxyl group and the 4-position methyl carbon atom. The same situation also appears in compounds 6 and 8. Compounds 4 and 6 display a similar meso-helical chain structure; however, the 2D supramolecular structure of 6 is slightly different from 4. In 6, the 4-position chlorine atom of HL4 are involved in the formation of C–H···Cl hydrogen bonds, which link adjacent chains into a 2D supramolecular layer parallel to the ac plane. Compound 10 also exhibits a meso-helical chain. Nevertheless, different from 4 and 6, C–H···Br hydrogen bonds between the methylene carbon atom and the 5-position bromine atom linked the chains to form a 2D supramolecular (44)-sql network in 10.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the central metals also have a remarkable effect on the formation of the final structures. The varieties in coordination numbers and atomic radius of the central metal atoms are the key reasons for the structural differences. Compounds [Zn2(L4)2(biim-4) (H2O)] 5 and [Cd(HL4)2(biim-4)] 6, [Zn2(L5)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 7 and [Cd(HL5)2(biim-4)1.5]·H2O 8, and [Zn2(L7)2(biim-4)2]·H2O 11 and [Cd2(L7)2(biim-4)2(H2O)]·H2O 12 exhibit the effects of coordination numbers on the complex structures. From the structures of 5 and 6, it can be seen that the coordination numbers of the Cd(II) ion in 6 is larger than that of the Zn(II) ion in 5, which results in quite distinct structures of 5 and 6. In 5, four/five-coordinated Zn(II) ions are bridged by L4 anions to yield a 1D wavelike chain. The chains are linked by two kinds of biim-4 ligands to generate a 3D 103-ths framework. However, in 6, six-coordinated Cd(II) ions are coordinated by two HL4 anions to form a [Cd(HL4)2] unit. Neighboring [Cd(HL4)2] units are bridged by biim-4 ligands to yield a meso-helical chain, which is extended into a 2D supramolecular layer through C–H···Cl hydrogen bonds. In 7, all the five-coordinated Zn(II) atoms are bridged by L5 anions to yield a wavelike 1D chain. The 1D chains are then connected by two kinds of biim-4 ligands to form a 3D diamond framework. Nevertheless, in 8, Cd(II) atoms are six-coordinated and connected by three kinds of biim-4 ligands to yield a 3-connected 63-hcb net. For compounds [Zn2(L7)2(biim-4)2]·H2O (11) and [Cd2(L7)2(biim-4)2(H2O)]·H2O (12), Zn(II) ions adopt the coordination numbers of 4 and 6, but Cd(II) ions employ the coordination numbers of 6 and 7, resulting in different (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with (4·53·72)(4·52·83) and (42.62.82)(42.6.82.10) topologies, respectively.

Effect of the Central Metal on the Framework

It is noteworthy that the central metals also have a remarkable effect on the formation of the final structures. The varieties in coordination numbers and atomic radius of the central metal atoms are the key reasons for the structural differences. Compounds [Zn2(L4)2(biim-4) (H2O)] 5 and [Cd(HL4)2(biim-4)] 6, [Zn2(L5)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 7 and [Cd(HL5)2(biim-4)1.5]⋅H2O 8, and [Zn2(L7)2(biim-4)2]⋅H2O 11 and [Cd2(L7)2(biim-4)2(H2O)]⋅H2O 12 exhibit the effects of coordination numbers on the complex structures. From the structures of 5 and 6, it can be seen that the coordination numbers of the Cd(II) ion in 6 is larger than that of the Zn(II) ion in 5, which results in quite distinct structures of 5 and 6. In 5, four/five-coordinated Zn(II) ions are bridged by L4 anions to yield a 1D wavelike chain. The chains are linked by two kinds of biim-4 ligands to generate a 3D 103-ths framework. However, in 6, six-coordinated Cd(II) ions are coordinated by two HL4 anions to form a [Cd(HL4)2] unit. Neighboring [Cd(HL4)2] units are bridged by biim-4 ligands to yield a meso-helical chain, which is extended into a 2D supramolecular layer through C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl hydrogen bonds. In 7, all the five-coordinated Zn(II) atoms are bridged by L5 anions to yield a wavelike 1D chain. The 1D chains are then connected by two kinds of biim-4 ligands to form a 3D diamond framework. Nevertheless, in 8, Cd(II) atoms are six-coordinated and connected by three kinds of biim-4 ligands to yield a 3-connected 63-hcb net. For compounds [Zn2(L7)2(biim-4)2]⋅H2O (11) and [Cd2(L7)2(biim-4)2(H2O)]⋅H2O (12), Zn(II) ions adopt the coordination numbers of 4 and 6, but Cd(II) ions employ the coordination numbers of 6 and 7, resulting in different (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with (4⋅53⋅72)(4⋅52⋅83) and (42.62.82)(42.6.82.10) topologies, respectively.

elements.content: Compounds [Zn2(L1)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 1 and [Cd(HL1)2(biim-4)] 2 as well as [Zn2(L6)2(biim-4)(H2O)] 9 and [Cd(HL6)2(biim-4)] 10 indicate the influence of atomic radius of central metal atoms on the frameworks. It is well-known that the radius of Cd(II) atom is larger than that of Zn(II) atom. Although both Zn(II) and Cd(II) atoms are five-coordinated in 1 and 2, their coordination environments are different. In 1, each Zn(II) atom is coordinated by two L1 anions and one biim-4 ligand, whereas, in 2, each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by two HL1 anions and two biim-4 ligands. Consequently, compound 1 displays a 3D 103-ths net, but compound 2 just exhibits a 1D chain structure. This structural difference caused by central metal atoms can also be supported by two structurally different compounds 9 and 10. Although both Zn(II) and Cd(II) atoms are five-coordinated in 9 and 10, their coordination environments are different. In 9, each Zn(II) ion is surrounded by four O atoms and one N atom, whereas, in 10, each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by three O atoms and two N atoms. Thus, 9 displays a 3D diamond framework, whereas compound 10 displays a 2D supramolecular (44)-sql network constructed by C–H···Br hydrogen bonds.

It is well-known that the radius of Cd(II) atom is larger than that of Zn(II) atom. Although both Zn(II) and Cd(II) atoms are five-coordinated in 1 and 2, their coordination environments are different. This structural difference caused by central metal atoms can also be supported by two structurally different compounds 9 and 10. Thus, 9 displays a 3D diamond framework, whereas compound 10 displays a 2D supramolecular (44)-sql network constructed by C-H⋅⋅⋅Br hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1–13. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the (Figures S9 and S10). They show that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD Results and Thermal Analysis

To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1-13. The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the  (Figures S9 and S10). They show that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for compounds 1–13 in order to characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability (). For compound 1, the weight loss corresponding to the release of one coordinated water molecule is observed from 241 to 265 °C (obsd 3.3%, calcd 2.95%). The weight loss from 328 to 559 °C is attributed to the collapse of the framework of 1. The remaining residue corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 27.7%, calcd 26.64%). For 2, the removal of the organic components occurs in the temperature range of 219–467 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to CdO (obsd 21.9%, calcd 22.26%). For compound 3, the weight loss corresponding to the release of organic ligands is observed from 217 to 502 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to the formation of CdO (obsd 23.0%, calcd 21.23%). The organic components of compound 4 decompose from 246 to 431 °C. The remaining residue corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd 21.3%, calcd 21.23%). Compound 5 shows three steps of weight losses. The first weight loss in the temperature range of 244–267 °C is consistent with the removal of one coordinated water molecule (obsd 3.0%, calcd 2.65%). The second weight loss from 267 to 519 °C is attributed to the release of the organic acids (obsd 51.0%, calcd 50.75%). The third weight loss from 519 to 565 °C corresponds to the removal of the biim-4 ligand (obsd 26.3%, calcd 27.97%). The remaining residue corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 21.1%, calcd 23.94%). The framework of compound 6 decomposes from 227 to 611 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to CdO (obsd 18.7%, calcd 19.88%). For 7, the weight loss of 2.8% in the temperature range of 239–282 °C is consistent with the removal of one coordinated water molecule (calcd 2.65%). The weight loss corresponding to the release of organic ligands is observed from 332 to 595 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to the formation of ZnO (obsd 22.0%, calcd 23.94%). Compound 8 lost its one lattice water molecule from 53 to 117 °C (obsd 2.5%, calcd 2.37%), and the decomposition of the residual composition occurs from 253 to 596 °C, leading to the formation of CdO as the residue (obsd 16.2%, calcd 16.92%). For 9, the removal of the organic components occurs in the temperature range of 236 to 627 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to the formation of ZnO (obsd 20.2%, calcd 21.17%). The organic components of compound 10 decompose from 226 to 431 °C. The remaining residue corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd 16.3%, calcd 17.48%). For compound 11, the weight loss in the range of 67–174 °C corresponds to the removal of one water molecule (obsd 1.8%, calcd 2.02%). The departure of the organic components occurs at 268 °C. For compound 12, the weight loss in the range of 58–276 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule (obsd 1.5%, calcd 1.79%), and one coordinated water molecule (obsd 2.1%, calcd 1.81%). The anhydrous compound begins to decompose at 296 °C. For compound 13, the weight loss in the temperature range of 57–162 °C can be attributed to the removal of half of a water molecule (obsd 1.6%, calcd 1.87%). The decomposition of the organic components occurs in the range of 227–612 °C. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 16.2%, calcd 16.90%).

elements.content: MOFs with d10 metal atoms are promising candidates for photoactive materials with potential applications. Solid-state luminescent studies were carried out for H2L1–H2L7 and H3L8 ligands (), as well as compounds 1–13 (Figure and Table ).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

MOFs with d10 metal atoms are promising candidates for photoactive materials with potential applications. Solid-state luminescent studies were carried out for H2L1-H2L7 and H3L8 ligands (), as well as compounds 1-13 (Figure  and Table ).

The main emission peak of biim-4 is at 438 nm (λex = 252 nm). The emissions of H2L1 (λem = 438 nm, λex = 289 nm), H2L2 (λem = 406 nm, λex = 337 nm), H2L3 (λem = 408 nm, λex =333 nm), H2L4 (λem = 428 nm, λex = 339), H2L5 (λem = 398 nm, λex = 313 nm), H2L6 (λem = 441 nm, λex = 310 nm), H2L7 (λem = 499 nm, λex = 314 nm), and H3L8 (λem = 436 nm, λex = 328 nm) can be assigned to the π* → n or π* → π transitions as previously reported. The emission peaks of Zn(II)-containing compounds occur at 402 nm (λex = 363 nm) for 1, 412 nm (λex = 286 nm) for 5, 408 nm (λex = 374 nm) for 7, 435 nm (λex = 309 nm) for 9, 566 nm (λex = 354 nm) for 11, and 425 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 13. The emission spectra for Cd(II)-containing compounds exhibit emission peaks at 418 nm (λex = 325 nm) for 2, 429 nm (λex = 323 nm) for 3, 424 nm (λex = 314 nm) for 4, 411 nm (λex = 293 nm) for 6, 445 nm (λex = 321 nm) for 8, 428 nm (λex = 321 nm) for 10, and 544 nm (λex = 294 nm) for 12. The emission peaks of compounds 1–13 are similar to those of the free organic acids. Since the Zn(II) and Cd(II) ions are difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to their d10 configuration, the emissions of compounds 1–13 are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature. As a result, the emission can be assigned to intraligand transitions.

elements.content: Interestingly, for 3, 4, 7, 8, 11, and 12, the emission peaks are red-shifted with respect to the free organic acids because of the replacement of the hydrogen atoms by Zn(II) or Cd(II) ions, which decreases the π* → n or π* → π gap of the salicylate ligands. However, compounds 1, 2, 5, 6, 9, 10, and 13 show blue-shifts relative to the free organic acids. This may be attributed to the coordination effects of the salicylate ligands to metal atoms, which increases the ligand conformational rigidity and reduces the nonradiative decay of the intraligand. The emission discrepancy of 1–13 is probably due to the differences of organic acids and coordination environments of central metal ions.

elements.content: A series of Zn/Cd-containing MOFs based on salicylate ligands and biim-4 ligand have been successfully prepared under similar synthetic conditions. These compounds display intriguing and versatile coordination features with 0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D frameworks. The structural differences show that structural features of organic anions have important effects on the structures of final products. Moreover, the varieties in coordination numbers and atomic radius of the central metal atoms also make a great contribution to the structural diversities of resultant compounds. The luminescent properties of the compounds 1–13 imply that some of them may be good candidates for luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of Zn/Cd-containing MOFs based on salicylate ligands and biim-4 ligand have been successfully prepared under similar synthetic conditions. These compounds display intriguing and versatile coordination features with 0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D frameworks. The structural differences show that structural features of organic anions have important effects on the structures of final products. Moreover, the varieties in coordination numbers and atomic radius of the central metal atoms also make a great contribution to the structural diversities of resultant compounds. The luminescent properties of the compounds 1-13 imply that some of them may be good candidates for luminescent materials.

elements.content: X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format, selected bond lengths and angles, coordination modes of organic anions, conformations of biim-4 ligands, structure illustrations for compounds 1, 2, 4–7, 9 and 11, PXRD patterns, thermogravimetric (TG) of the compounds 1–13, emission spectra of the reported organic acids. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

cln_elements.content:
From the topological view, Cd1 and Cd2 atoms can be regarded as two kinds of 4-connected nodes, and L7 anions and biim-4 ligands can be simplified as linkers. Thus, the 3D framework of 12 can be described as a binodal (4,4)-connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of (42.62.82)(42.6.82.10) (Figure d).

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out for compounds 1–13 in order to characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability (). For compound 1, the weight loss corresponding to the release of one coordinated water molecule is observed from 241 to 265 °C (obsd 3.3%, calcd 2.95%). The weight loss from 328 to 559 °C is attributed to the collapse of the framework of 1. The remaining residue corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 27.7%, calcd 26.64%). For 2, the removal of the organic components occurs in the temperature range of 219–467 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to CdO (obsd 21.9%, calcd 22.26%). For compound 3, the weight loss corresponding to the release of organic ligands is observed from 217 to 502 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to the formation of CdO (obsd 23.0%, calcd 21.23%). The organic components of compound 4 decompose from 246 to 431 °C. The remaining residue corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd 21.3%, calcd 21.23%). Compound 5 shows three steps of weight losses. The first weight loss in the temperature range of 244–267 °C is consistent with the removal of one coordinated water molecule (obsd 3.0%, calcd 2.65%). The second weight loss from 267 to 519 °C is attributed to the release of the organic acids (obsd 51.0%, calcd 50.75%). The third weight loss from 519 to 565 °C corresponds to the removal of the biim-4 ligand (obsd 26.3%, calcd 27.97%). The remaining residue corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 21.1%, calcd 23.94%). The framework of compound 6 decomposes from 227 to 611 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to CdO (obsd 18.7%, calcd 19.88%). For 7, the weight loss of 2.8% in the temperature range of 239–282 °C is consistent with the removal of one coordinated water molecule (calcd 2.65%). The weight loss corresponding to the release of organic ligands is observed from 332 to 595 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to the formation of ZnO (obsd 22.0%, calcd 23.94%). Compound 8 lost its one lattice water molecule from 53 to 117 °C (obsd 2.5%, calcd 2.37%), and the decomposition of the residual composition occurs from 253 to 596 °C, leading to the formation of CdO as the residue (obsd 16.2%, calcd 16.92%). For 9, the removal of the organic components occurs in the temperature range of 236 to 627 °C. The remaining residue is assigned to the formation of ZnO (obsd 20.2%, calcd 21.17%). The organic components of compound 10 decompose from 226 to 431 °C. The remaining residue corresponds to the formation of CdO (obsd 16.3%, calcd 17.48%). For compound 11, the weight loss in the range of 67–174 °C corresponds to the removal of one water molecule (obsd 1.8%, calcd 2.02%). The departure of the organic components occurs at 268 °C. For compound 12, the weight loss in the range of 58–276 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule (obsd 1.5%, calcd 1.79%), and one coordinated water molecule (obsd 2.1%, calcd 1.81%). The anhydrous compound begins to decompose at 296 °C. For compound 13, the weight loss in the temperature range of 57–162 °C can be attributed to the removal of half of a water molecule (obsd 1.6%, calcd 1.87%). The decomposition of the organic components occurs in the range of 227–612 °C. The remaining weight corresponds to the formation of ZnO (obsd 16.2%, calcd 16.90%).
